All right, so today we're

same base babka dough.

Into the bowl of a stand
mixer goes 550 grams

of all-purpose flour,
tiny whisked together

with two and a half

Then, in a separate bowl,
we're combining two thirds

of cup of milk, warmed to
80 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit,

with two large eggs, 55
grams of granulated sugar,
and two teaspoons of kosher salt,

optionally adding one
teaspoon of vanilla paste
if you're making a sweet babka.

Add that to the stand
mixer along with 140 grams
of unsalted butter at room temperature
and set about kneading with a dough hook

for six to eight minutes
once everything is combined.

In the end, you should
have a smooth bouncy dough

that just barely passes
the windowpane test.
This recipe makes two loaves,
so we're gonna divide that dough in half.
Then I'm gonna laminate each piece.

That is, roll it out
and fold it into thirds

to try to get it into a
more rectangular shape.

Then ideally, we're gonna
wrap it plastic wrap

and fridge it overnight, but
if you want same day babka,

you can place it in a
covered bowl and let it rise
at room temperature for one hour.
Next up, we need to make our filling,
and I'm gonna start with cinnamon.

Into a large bowl goes
250 grams of brown sugar,

30 grams of all-purpose
flour, two tablespoons

of ground cinnamon, and a
half teaspoon of kosher salt.

Once combined, I'm adding
140 grams of unsalted

melted butter, along with one

Set that aside, fetch your dough,

so I put little gobs all

spreading into a thin even

Now we're gonna optionally
rotate the dough 90 degrees

and then roll up the

Longways? Is that what you call this?

You see what I'm doing.
Pinching the end of the dough together

Then we need to slice

Then we have to thoroughly

Now our loaf emerges from the freezer,

so we can cut it in
half cleanly lengthwise.
I used that word correctly.

Then I'm gonna press and
squeeze out each length

line them up parallel,

and press their ends together
with the heel of my hand,

making sure the doughs
kind of seal together

before I start twisting the
two ends around each other,
trying to keep the cut side facing upward
as I form the loaf.
Once the dough's been twisted together,

we're gonna seal the
other end the same way

with the palm our hand,
pressing and smearing

and tucking it underneath
loaf to make sure
that it doesn't come apart during baking.
And then if you want an extra layer

outside of your loaf,

The citeration.

Now we're gonna tuck

trying to push the ends

covering it with a moist
clean kitchen towel

temperature for one hour,
or until roughly doubled in size.
While that rises, for this loaf,

we're gonna make a
streusel, combining 85 grams

of light brown sugar, 60
grams of all-purpose flour,

and a half teaspoon of
kosher salt in a small bowl.

Mix up the dry boys
until they're homogenous,

of melted unsalted butter.

This should form a crumbly
sort of wet sand mixture

that we can then sprinkle
generously over the top
of our risen loaf.

Place this guy onto a rimed
baking sheet to catch any

errant drops, pop him into a
preheated 350-degree Fahrenheit

oven for 45 to 55 minutes
until deeply brown

and its thickest point registers
185 degrees Fahrenheit.
Let it cool in the pan for 10 minutes

before letting it cool
completely on a wire rack,
at least two hours.
Slice in and serve.

up with as many layers

This can be solved by

soft, crunchy, the works.

But what about the
classic chocolate babka?

For that, in a double boiler,
we need to melt 190 grams
of chopped dark chocolate and 115 grams
of unsalted butter, room temperature.
Once totally melted but not overheated,

we're gonna take it off
the heat, add 80 grams

of powdered sugar, 35 grams
of unsweetened cocoa powder,
a half teaspoon of cinnamon,
and a quarter teaspoon of kosher salt.
Mix that together into a spreadable paste,

and then from there it's the
same procedure as before.

Spread half the mixture
out onto half of our dough,

roll up, freeze, cut,
twist, rise, and bake,
this time the only difference being,

once it comes out of the
oven, while it's still hot,

we're gonna brush it
down with simple syrup,
which is gonna help give the loaf
its characteristic burnished sheen.

You could also make this one
with streusel if you wanted,

or you could dust it with

or just slice it up as is.

loaf as social media ready
as it is delicious.
But what about savory babka?
You heard me right.

This time, in a bowl
we're combining 225 grams

softened, with three tablespoons
of everything bagel seasoning.

This is gonna make a soft,
spreadable mixture that we can,

you know, spread on our
babka like the other stuff,
treating it the exact same
all the way up to the point of baking.

This time, we're gonna brush
our guy down with a beaten egg,

both for color and to adhere
more everything bagel seasoning

that we're gonna sprinkle
generously over top.

Pop this guy in the oven
for the same amount of time

until the same internal
temperature is reached,
and you'll end up with what is decidedly

not a traditional babka,
but one that is extremely,

extremely delicious, about as
